AF.content: death drive destroys archives, anarchic, destroys its own trace, operates in silence
AF.linkedContent: death drive destroys archives, anarchic, destroys its own trace, operates in silence

AF.content: leaves no monument/document of its own > as inheritance, leaves on its erotic simulacrum (erogenous color draws mask on skin): origin of beautiful > memories of death
AF.linkedContent: leaves no monument/document of its own > as inheritance, leaves on its erotic simulacrum (erogenous color draws mask on skin): origin of beautiful > memories of death

SH.content: name partakes in this destiny of ash along w/ date, not empirical, is part of its readability; mourning: reading itself > readability: tribute of lost singularity (“beauty” pays)
SH.linkedContent: name partakes in this destiny of ash along w/ date, not empirical, is part of its readability; mourning: reading itself > readability: tribute of lost singularity (“beauty” pays)

P.content: for Hegel, telos of beauty is found in art not nature; for Hegel, there’s almost no natural beauty, and it is inferior to beauty produced by mind
P.linkedContent: for Hegel, telos of beauty is found in art not nature; for Hegel, there’s almost no natural beauty, and it is inferior to beauty produced by mind

P.content: for Hegel, only philosophy can pose question “What is the beautiful?” and answer it: it’s a production of art, i.e. the mind
P.linkedContent: for Hegel, only philosophy can pose question “What is the beautiful?” and answer it: it’s a production of art, i.e. the mind

P.content: for Kant, beauty is universality w/out concept—necessitates an analogy, occupation of nonconceptual field by the grid (quadrillage) of conceptual force: sans et avec [concept] en même temps (ama)
P.linkedContent: for Kant, beauty is universality w/out concept—necessitates an analogy, occupation of nonconceptual field by the grid (quadrillage) of conceptual force: sans et avec [concept] en même temps (ama)

P.content: for Kant, pure sound & pure color as vibration of ether > purely formal, “universally compatible w/ certainty”—beautiful [what about color gold on frame?]
P.linkedContent: for Kant, pure sound & pure color as vibration of ether > purely formal, “universally compatible w/ certainty”—beautiful [what about color gold on frame?]

P.content: Kant: examples are wheelchairs (Gängelwagen) [roulettes] of judgment, those who don’t have enough Mutterwitz, the sick, need these wheelchairs, prostheses that replace nothing
P.linkedContent: Kant: examples are wheelchairs (Gängelwagen) [roulettes] of judgment, those who don’t have enough Mutterwitz, the sick, need these wheelchairs, prostheses that replace nothing

P.content: Hegel: there is play in examples, they play, Beispielen
P.linkedContent: Hegel: there is play in examples, they play, Beispielen

P.content: Derrida, via Hegel: examples divert energy of ergon, introduce chance & abyss into necessity of Mutterwitz > this can make one lose one’s head, a Russian roulette (death drive and mourning of labor in experience of beautiful), to put into play pleasure w/out enjoyment
P.linkedContent: Derrida, via Hegel: examples divert energy of ergon, introduce chance & abyss into necessity of Mutterwitz > this can make one lose one’s head, a Russian roulette (death drive and mourning of labor in experience of beautiful), to put into play pleasure w/out enjoyment

P.content: Kant’s beauty [wild tulip] requires absolute interruption: straining toward end w/out goal, not pure if cut can be bandaged (pansable), no pure cut (if it could be prolonged, completed, supplemented), no beauty > everything in it straining toward the bout (end, blow)
P.linkedContent: Kant’s beauty [wild tulip] requires absolute interruption: straining toward end w/out goal, not pure if cut can be bandaged (pansable), no pure cut (if it could be prolonged, completed, supplemented), no beauty > everything in it straining toward the bout (end, blow)

P.content: this fascination w/out desire, in view of an end never in view, a but en blanc [“point blank”] > interrupted finality must show itself as finality & interrupture, as edging
P.linkedContent: this fascination w/out desire, in view of an end never in view, a but en blanc [“point blank”] > interrupted finality must show itself as finality & interrupture, as edging

P.content: it is the sans that counts for beauty, la bordure [edging] en sans de la coupure pure
P.linkedContent: it is the sans that counts for beauty, la bordure [edging] en sans de la coupure pure

P.content: nonknowledge is point of view whose irreducibility gives rise to the beautiful (purity of the trace of the sans) > Kant: no science of the beautiful, only critique
P.linkedContent: nonknowledge is point of view whose irreducibility gives rise to the beautiful (purity of the trace of the sans) > Kant: no science of the beautiful, only critique

P.content: beautiful object, tulip, not lacking in anything, tel point de vue, de but en blanc, plie la totalité à se manquer elle-même > le sans de la coupure pure est sans manque—but for me to experience its totality, my knowledge lacks something—its end (bout); not the absence of end but the trace of the without [end] is origin of beauty; ça donne-le-beau: beauty gives nothing to be seen, sans is not visible, et pourtant il y en a et c’est beau
P.linkedContent: beautiful object, tulip, not lacking in anything, tel point de vue, de but en blanc, plie la totalité à se manquer elle-même > le sans de la coupure pure est sans manque—but for me to experience its totality, my knowledge lacks something—its end (bout); not the absence of end but the trace of the without [end] is origin of beauty; ça donne-le-beau: beauty gives nothing to be seen, sans is not visible, et pourtant il y en a et c’est beau

P.content: Kant’s 2 beauties: 1) freie Schönheit (pulchritudo vaga [indefinite, vague]), w/out end, limit, pure 2) bloss anhängende Schönheit (pulchritudo adhaerens [adherent beauty]), “de-pendent on”
P.linkedContent: Kant’s 2 beauties: 1) freie Schönheit (pulchritudo vaga [indefinite, vague]), w/out end, limit, pure 2) bloss anhängende Schönheit (pulchritudo adhaerens [adherent beauty]), “de-pendent on”

P.content: free, vague, wild, pure beauty, indefinite errance: elle ne s’arrive pas à sa destination ——paradox of 3rd Critique: singularities must give rise to universalizable judgments > Kant’s free beauty: self-subsisting, always beautiful once
P.linkedContent: free, vague, wild, pure beauty, indefinite errance: elle ne s’arrive pas à sa destination ——paradox of 3rd Critique: singularities must give rise to universalizable judgments > Kant’s free beauty: self-subsisting, always beautiful once

P.content: concepts stitch up (recoudre), furnish supplement of adherence [re: completes incomplete gadget]; still, there’s a chiasma, w/ free beauty, la coupure n’y laisse aucune peau, aucun tissu d’adhérence: law w/out concept, w/out debt, complete because incomplete
P.linkedContent: concepts stitch up (recoudre), furnish supplement of adherence [re: completes incomplete gadget]; still, there’s a chiasma, w/ free beauty, la coupure n’y laisse aucune peau, aucun tissu d’adhérence: law w/out concept, w/out debt, complete because incomplete

P.content: une fleur belle est toujours en ce sens une fleur absolument coupable absolument absoute [sic], innocente ——envy, jealousy, mortification at work w/in our affect > the beautiful this does w/out everything, w/out you, w/out its class > quasi-narcissistic independence of beautiful
P.linkedContent: une fleur belle est toujours en ce sens une fleur absolument coupable absolument absoute [sic], innocente ——envy, jealousy, mortification at work w/in our affect > the beautiful this does w/out everything, w/out you, w/out its class > quasi-narcissistic independence of beautiful

P.content: what is beautiful is dissemination, pure cut w/out negativity; negativity is significant; adherence always connotes division, lack, negativity; beauty is not a signifier; the signifier: accounts for everything except beauty > a non-sterilized cut from fecundation: la semence s’erre
P.linkedContent: what is beautiful is dissemination, pure cut w/out negativity; negativity is significant; adherence always connotes division, lack, negativity; beauty is not a signifier; the signifier: accounts for everything except beauty > a non-sterilized cut from fecundation: la semence s’erre

P.content: beauty w/out enunciated rules, judgment w/out concept, mute, open mouth (parole soufflée)
P.linkedContent: beauty w/out enunciated rules, judgment w/out concept, mute, open mouth (parole soufflée)

P.content: [Kant on the exemplary, exemplary w/out concept, natural/artificial free beauties]
P.linkedContent: [Kant on the exemplary, exemplary w/out concept, natural/artificial free beauties]

P.content: [Derrida makes his move] Kant assigns free beauty to framing-foliation, signifying nothing > having to be interrupted, sans-theme & sans-text relate to end as nonrelation, finality w/out end, but this sans must be marked, the trace [?] > parergon: place/structure of free beauty?
P.linkedContent: [Derrida makes his move] Kant assigns free beauty to framing-foliation, signifying nothing > having to be interrupted, sans-theme & sans-text relate to end as nonrelation, finality w/out end, but this sans must be marked, the trace [?] > parergon: place/structure of free beauty?

P.content: isn’t the frame exactly what Kant means by free-wandering beauty? but, unlike frame, that which is beautiful tends towards meaning, a tension, vection, rection that must be absolutely interrupted [from concept, end] to liberate beauty [not stopgap of sublime, though]
P.linkedContent: isn’t the frame exactly what Kant means by free-wandering beauty? but, unlike frame, that which is beautiful tends towards meaning, a tension, vection, rection that must be absolutely interrupted [from concept, end] to liberate beauty [not stopgap of sublime, though]

P.content: adherent/vague beauty cannot relate—is there a frame btwn them? suspending relation, puts them in relation > which is the example of which?
P.linkedContent: adherent/vague beauty cannot relate—is there a frame btwn them? suspending relation, puts them in relation > which is the example of which?

P.content: pure telos of beauty (as non-telos), telos of 2 beauties would be sans, nonpresentation of telos
P.linkedContent: pure telos of beauty (as non-telos), telos of 2 beauties would be sans, nonpresentation of telos

P.content: conceptual determination of end limits free play (of imagination): sans opens play w/in beauty
P.linkedContent: conceptual determination of end limits free play (of imagination): sans opens play w/in beauty

P.content: one must choose btwn not seeing beauty & seeing the end
P.linkedContent: one must choose btwn not seeing beauty & seeing the end

P.content: the strange fact that the median propositions (those on free beauty) in Kant’s Critique remain suspended, lack immediate justification—though magnetized by their end
P.linkedContent: the strange fact that the median propositions (those on free beauty) in Kant’s Critique remain suspended, lack immediate justification—though magnetized by their end

P.content: perfection [teleological end, purpose] often confused w/ beauty, Kant breaks from this tradition > judgment of taste does not bear on perfection of object, its internal possibility of existence—those examples (man, horse, buildings) which only have adherent beauty always have relation to man [Kant’s beauty as anti-anthropological in its anti-perfection] [the subjective finality or finality w/out end (beauty) vs. objective finality]
P.linkedContent: perfection [teleological end, purpose] often confused w/ beauty, Kant breaks from this tradition > judgment of taste does not bear on perfection of object, its internal possibility of existence—those examples (man, horse, buildings) which only have adherent beauty always have relation to man [Kant’s beauty as anti-anthropological in its anti-perfection] [the subjective finality or finality w/out end (beauty) vs. objective finality]

P.content: the horse is so much a part of man’s telos, it can never achieve errant, free beauty, unable to disregard its objective finality which can only be external
P.linkedContent: the horse is so much a part of man’s telos, it can never achieve errant, free beauty, unable to disregard its objective finality which can only be external

P.content: in Kant, sans of free beauty compressed/oriented by regulatory idea of maximal consensus among men [universal?]
P.linkedContent: in Kant, sans of free beauty compressed/oriented by regulatory idea of maximal consensus among men [universal?]

P.content: beauty & sublime: please by themselves, independent of judgment of senses & determinate judgments, pretension to universal validity on side of pleasure (not knowledge), both reflexive judgments > beautiful (finite) requires parergon, presence of limit gives form to beautiful, this bordered edging not only externally limited but called in by hollowing of lacunary quality w/in the work (ergon) > colossal/sublime excludes parergon, not ergon, usually nature, “w/out limit”
P.linkedContent: beauty & sublime: please by themselves, independent of judgment of senses & determinate judgments, pretension to universal validity on side of pleasure (not knowledge), both reflexive judgments > beautiful (finite) requires parergon, presence of limit gives form to beautiful, this bordered edging not only externally limited but called in by hollowing of lacunary quality w/in the work (ergon) > colossal/sublime excludes parergon, not ergon, usually nature, “w/out limit”

P.content: beauty: w/out interest; sublime: counter-interest
P.linkedContent: beauty: w/out interest; sublime: counter-interest

FS.content: for Kant, [productive] imagination was already art itself > originally, did not distinguish btwn beauty & truth
FS.linkedContent: for Kant, [productive] imagination was already art itself > originally, did not distinguish btwn beauty & truth

FS.content: medieval theology (Considérans): all forms, even monsters, beautiful, Formosus means beautiful > form is transcendentally beautifully: it is [Being] and makes things be [creating]
FS.linkedContent: medieval theology (Considérans): all forms, even monsters, beautiful, Formosus means beautiful > form is transcendentally beautifully: it is [Being] and makes things be [creating]

C.content: one cannot get to it in one go (d’un coup): multiplication shows that that which touches on the series is outside the series in the series > the remainder remains cut off, a mors, a turd, really beautiful

TN.content: Psyche as Mary, beautiful for being neither dead nor alive: surviving

E.content: why call them Fine-Arts (Beaux-Arts)? why not just call the product beautiful: because the product must still be implicated by its signature, beauty is ascribed to the passage btwn production/product; Fine-Arts: always of the frame & signature
